description: From Middle English rare, from Old French rare, rere (“rare, uncommon”), from Latin rārus (“loose, spaced apart, thin, infrequent”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reh₁- (“friable, thin”). Replaced native Middle English gesen (“rare, scarce”) (from Old English gǣsne), Middle English seld (“rare, uncommon”) (from Old English selden), and Middle English seldscene (“rare, rarely seen, infrequent”) (from Old English seldsēne).

examples: Black pearls are very rare and therefore very valuable.
Synonyms: scarce, selcouth, seld, selly, geason, uncommon; see also Thesaurus:rare
Antonyms: common, frequent; see also Thesaurus:common

entries.meaning: (of a gas) Thin; of low density.

examples: Sees her reflection in a butcher shop.
She finds it all quite rare
That her meat's all vanity fair.

Most of the time, you do this by trading low-valued rares for more valuable ones or trading uncommons for rares. Other times it's trading cards that are in print for ones that are out of print, or low-value rares for good uncommons.

description: From a dialectal variant of rear, from Middle English rere, from Old English hrēr, hrēre (“not thoroughly cooked, underdone, lightly boiled”), from hrēran (“to move, shake, agitate”), from Proto-Germanic *hrōzijaną (“to stir”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱroHs- (“to mix, stir, cook”). Related to Old English hrōr (“stirring, busy, active, strong, brave”). More at rear.

adjectives.description: rare (comparative rarer or more rare, superlative rarest or most rare)

entries.meaning: (cooking) Particularly of meat, especially beefsteak: cooked very lightly, so the meat is still red.

verbs.description: rare (third-person singular simple present rares, present participle raring, simple past and past participle rared)

entries.meaning: (US, intransitive) To rear, rise up, start backwards.
examples: Frank pretended to rare back as if bedazzled, shielding his eyes with a forearm.

entries.meaning: (US, transitive) To rear, bring up, raise.

adjectives.description: rare (comparative more rare, superlative most rare)
